Hell, the past month we've had Project 2025 and his child rape go viral. I can't imagine there's a large amount of people who would change their voting stance on Trump over this.

We don't even have details yet. Could have been an airsoft gun for all the damage it did.

More importantly Trump is a coward. This will have him shook. He will over react, a statesmans reaction won't be in the cards here. He'll either come across afraid, or more likely out for blood. Do you know how that will play with the average voter? Especially when his brown shirts get in on the game. For better or worse this is still the dem's election to lose.

> Wes Streeting, the Health Secretary, intends to stop powerful hormone blockers being given to children via any means, subject to the outcome of a legal hearing.

So it’s not even going to be legal as a treatment for precocious puberty? Is someone finally being consistent and saying both uses are dangerous? I hope so, because we have decades of data saying otherwise.
Don't be stupid, of course they've been quick to reaffirm that your cis kids will still be able to get their medication.
This argument just feels like a silver bullet to me. I don’t know how anyone who hears it could argue against it with anything other than basic transphobic rhetoric.

if you want to look at the argument in the best possible light, which is often really helpful for arguing *against* things, the question of whether or not puberty blockers are safe for trans kids does not refer to the effects of the drug in a vaccum, it refers to the question of whether or not its safe for a child's development to stop or significantly delay puberty.

for example, alcohol causes liver damage - thats an inherent property of alcohol that isnt dependent on how you use it or other personal factors. we know from extensive use in kids with precocious puberty that there are not any significant risks like this coming from puberty blockers. its not as if the drugs, independent of their other effects, cause cancer or organ damage or whatever potential negative effect you want to consider.

the difference is that in kids with precocious puberty, puberty blockers are used to kinda normalize the process of puberty, so that it happens more in line with the average experience of a kid going thru puberty. they are used to achieve what most people would consider "normal" puberty.

however in trans kids, they are used to stop, reduce or delay puberty. the question of whether or not they are safe to use for this purpose does not have anything to do with the inherent risks of the drug itself, like the risk of liver damage from alcohol, the question of safety refers to whether or not its safe to delay or stop puberty. in theory, the same questions would apply if you had a magic wand you could wave to stop puberty for trans kids with no drugs at all.

i notice this *alot* in discussions on puberty blockers and it often results in people kinda talking past each other and not addressing the actual concerns. the question of safety is not "is this drug safe for the human body?", its "is stopping or delaying puberty safe for the human body?" it seems like there is good evidence coming out that it *is* safe to delay puberty, and those are the arguments that should be focused on, because simply arguing that the drug itself is apparently well tolerated by the human body is missing the point of the opposition.

> it refers to the question of whether or not its safe for a child's development to stop or significantly delay puberty.

And the obvious point to bring up after that is that Cass herself said that the overwhelming majority of kids who go onto puberty blockers because they're trans go on to transition.  So if puberty blockers are dangerous for trans kids, then why don't we just give them HRT instead?

> So if puberty blockers are dangerous for trans kids, then why don't we just give them HRT instead?

i assume because there would be the same questions of how it effects a child's development to do that during puberty, and the main reason, which is given by pretty much all gender care professionals, is that puberty blockers are given in order to delay puberty while the trans kid has more time to grow as a person and decide for sure that they want the more serious changes that come from HRT. i dont really feel like "well just do the more extreme treatment right away because most kids end up wanting it anyway" is going to be a very convincing argument for people who are on the fence about gender care for minors, and afaik that's not even the preferred treatment path for gender care clinics who support gender affirming care for minors in general.

**Why Bernie and AOC Defending Biden Against Dropping Out Was Not A Strategic Blunder But Strategic Survival For Progressives and The Left** 


.


While Biden has dropped out and Kamala Harris has dropped in for the presidential race, I don't think Bernie and AOC defending Biden against the calls for Biden to drop out were a strategic blunder but instead an example of strategic survival for progressives and the Left. And while AOC's livestream was messy and rambly (I believe Beau of the Fifth Column's video about the difficulties of the logistics of replacing Biden is shorter and more concise), Vaush "I Know More Than A Sitting Congressperson Because I Read Headline Out Loud For A Living And Barely Ever Go Outside" Kochinski's response to the livestream was incoherent dogshit. Let's not kid ourselves with Vaush's bad arguments in regards to that video, which were on par with his bad media takes or his atrocious zero IQ  take on motorbikes and Vespas. 

.


Anyways, I think the main reason why Bernie and AOC were so dogged in defending Biden till the end was because they were hyper aware of the optics of what it would look like and who would get blamed HARD if it was the Progressives who were leading the charge in calling for Biden to drop out. They would get done dirty by the centrist corporate Dems in case Biden or Harris lost the election in the scenario where the Progressives were one of the ones calling for Biden to drop out. Progressives had influence and rapport with Biden, something they wouldn't have with some centrist Dem replacement and they wanted to protect that rapport and goodwill. So by instead defending Biden from the calls to drop out from the centrist Dems, they at least protect the bridge of goodwill and reciprocity they have with Biden which will hopefully transfer to Harris and it helps the Progressives optically and politically at that (as I'm sure Bernie and AOC got some concessions out of Biden for their support). Sure, they got some egg in the face for defending Biden from dropping out till the end but it is NOT *nearly* as bad as it would be if it was portrayed optically for the Progressives if they were portrayed as the ones leading the charge in calling for Biden to drop out. Endorsing Kamala Harris will be no skin off the nose for Progressives. 

.

Because Bernie, AOC, and co. held the line for Biden  to the end, they not only saved Progressives optically in the long run but they also kept the bridge with Biden open and strong which is very important for one VERY big reason. Wile Kamala is the one running for election, Biden is still the POTUS until January 2025. Without the stress of re-election burdening him, Biden is more free and open to act in ways that he normally wouldn't be able to  willing to do with the thought of reelection. While this won't mean he'll go Ultra Dark Brandon and order any assassinations, it does open up an avenue for Biden to actually improve his handling of Gaza and to actually be harder on Netanyahu and Israel, among other things both domestically and abroad. Let's honestly ask ourselves, do you think Biden would be open and receptive to Progressives in the scenario where they were one of the ones who were calling for him to drop out? Or would Biden be MUCH more open and receptive to Progressives in the present scenario where Progressives held the line till the end of defending Biden from the calls for him to drop out by the centrist Dems who Biden was more ideologically aligned with, and thus protecting the bridge of goodwill, rapport, and influence that they have with Biden? The answer is obviously the latter. 

.

Bernie, AOC, and co.  defending Biden from the calls to drop out till the end was not a strategic blunder but strategic survival for Progressives and the Left. In dropping out of re-election, Joe Biden is now unburdened by what has been. And with the Progressives protecting the bridge they have with him till the end, Biden is unburdened enough and receptive to be influenced to more progressive policy ends and executive actions. The chances are much higher now compared to the alternative scenario.

It seems to be an incredibly common mantra in left wing communities that what is far more important than voting is to focus on building our communities and solidarity. And every time I hear it I roll my eyes internally. Being blunt this seems like a do nothing phrase that is far more mantric than it is useful.

What does it actually mean to build solidarity and community when the prospect we face is a  militarized fascist state? Do folks seriously think that their left wing book club or community garden is going to prevent a secret police force from black bagging them in the night? Do they think a mountain commune they establish won’t be raided and destroyed by a state determined to wipe them out? Or is this a more grandiose Les Mis situation where if they’re going to go out they want to go out with a drizzle of melancholy rain and a stirring violin solo?

I think, and call me a lib or whatever, that lots of folks on the left are not familiar with how government works, are frustrated that it is slow when abiding by “the rules” and they have a romantic idea of a revolution against the state. And all these together lead to a smug superior attitude of inaction while denigrating the only real tool we have under our belts, the ballot.

I’d really like someone to explain to me what this actually means or if it is what I think it is, a coping phrase to absolve inaction or to make inaction seem like Praxis.

Honestly, I am at a point where elections feel more and more like kicking the can down the road and not an attempt to prevent fascism but delay its inevitable rise (let alone make the world a better place). Will I still vote? Yeah. But good God it is hard to blame people from being demoralized or staying home or voting third party when someone like Biden is the best the Dems can do.

& Will Cost Him The Election.

We’re in an era of nail-biter,  highly competitive presidential elections.

Since 2000 with the Exemption of Obama’s 2 races  In 2020, Joe Biden won three states by less than a 4 percentage point, including Wisconsin, the state that notched him an Electoral College victory. (Obama is the only person in the 2000s to win Wisconsin by more than 1%...)

In 2016, that exact statement applied to Donald Trump. Polls today suggest 2024 will be similarly close. The get-out-the-vote operations, the so-called “ground game,” may determine the outcome in November.

Cuz, The Trump campaign is tasking the far-right Turning Point network with spearheading its ground game despite having no track record of success.

CNN reported that “Donald Trump’s campaign is taking a vastly different approach to 2024 compared with 2020, with plans for fewer staff and expenses [and instead] relying on wealthy conservative groups for data, infrastructure, and significant bank accounts.” It further noted that one of the most important of these groups  is Charli Kirk’s  group

Conservative donors have rewarded the Turning Point network for its virulence with more cash every year. The group reported $9.8 million in donations for 2017, $79.2 million for 2022, and a quarter of a billion since 2016.

But the ability to vacuum up cash does not automatically translate into the ability to boost voter turnout.

In 2022, the Turning Point network entered the ground game business, mainly in Arizona, where it is headquartered. As the Arizona Republic reported, “Turning Point PAC, the political action committee started by Turning Point USA, spent $494,105 during the 2022 election cycle, including the primary elections. The bulk of that, $377,201, went towards the general election races for U.S. Senate, governor, and Secretary of State in Arizona.”

Turning Point’s candidates lost all of those races.

Kari Lake, led the Democratic nominee, Katie Hobbs, by 2.4 percentage points in the final FiveThirtyEight poll average. Yet Hobbs won by a 0.7 percentage point margin. Underperforming the polls by 3 points indicates that Lake and her Turning Point comrades got beat on the ground.

Undeterred, Turning Point last year began shopping around a $108 million get-out-the-vote plan, now called “Chase the Vote,” focusing on Arizona, Georgia, and Wisconsin.

Then-Chair of the Republican National Committee, Ronna McDaniel, gave this plan the cold shoulder. Kirk launched blistering attacks on McDaniel, claiming she was a Democratic plant and urging Trump to dump her. According to Real Clear Politics, McDaniel told Trump that Kirk’s penchant for insulting African Americans, such as saying Martin Luther King, Jr. did not deserve a holiday, would hurt efforts with Black voters.

Kirk won the fight. McDaniel quit under pressure. Then Trump took Kirk’s suggestion to install his daughter-in-law, Lara Trump, as RNC co-chair.
Republicans suspicious of Kirk told NBC News soon after McDaniel’s February ouster that Kirk pushed for it so Turning Point could take over the 2024 ground game and profit from it:

At the “Restoring National Confidence” summit, hosted by Turning Point Action ahead of this month’s RNC winter meetings in Las Vegas, state and local GOP chairs were pitched on transitioning their voter outreach and canvassing efforts to an app created by Superfeed Technologies, a company led by Tyler Bowyer, the chief operating officer of Turning Point USA.

“This is why he was trying to get rid of Ronna,” [a] Trump ally said. “He shouldn’t make it sound like, ‘Oh, we’re tired of losing. We don’t have an early vote program.’ He should have just said, ‘Listen, he who controls the RNC controls millions of dollars and I want to get my hands on them.’ I mean, that would have been a more honest grift.”

Trump usually likes to hustle rather than be hustled. What would entice him to fall for Turning Point’s scheme? Probably because “Chase the Vote” is premised on a political strategy that comports with Trump’s extremist politics: forget the swing, juice the base.

As CNN reported: “The prevailing wisdom of the consultant class before was, ‘Let’s go to those swing districts and really try and move those voters.’ Well, we don’t agree,” one source familiar with the plans told CNN. “We’re going where the Republicans are. We’re going to drive up [the] score in those areas and get the people that stayed home in 2020 or 2022.”

This is the logic Turning Point used in 2022 when it struck out in all the major Arizona races. But it’s a comfortable strategy for Trump to accept because he need not woo swing voters.

In some progressive circles, base-only strategies have been trendy in recent years. But Democratic leaders have largely eschewed such insular thinking and Also courted swing voters, to Combine with Base, which paid off in 2018, 2020, and 2022, Helping in The Suburbs

For those of you who think ai art is real art, do you get as much satisfaction killing bots in fortnite as if you kill a real player?

AI is just the latest form of anti-art.

AI using data scraped from the internet it has no rights to use is bad. Everything else is just subjective.

Yeah, that’s how I look at it. Companies using it so save money and not hire actual artists is scummy, but if someone is hosting a dnd campaign and wants some cool art, they can use ai to their hearts content. My opinions on the subject really vary on a case by case basis

Yeah that's not morally wrong, but its not art.  
  
Generative images are never art, but they are products. And you are allowed to like a product.

Do you think photography is art? 

Photography is widely considered a sub genre of art. Its also closely analogous to using AI, even ignoring that a lot of the professional editing tools use AI. 

The "artist" uses a tool to capture an image of something they didn't create, they pick the best from a volume, then further manipulate in various ways until they get the correct outcome. 

I honestly don't think I care either way or have much of an opinion. I just don't think the answer is definitely no when people can tape bananas to walls and sell it as an art instillation. Art by definition is always subjective, and the most I feel comfortable saying is what isn't art to me might be art to you. So surely it is art in some form?

>Do you think photography is art?

Yep. There's a clear artistic vision that is realized by the artist through their work.

If you think the process of photography is anything like generative images, then you are either woefully misinformed about photography or generative images.

Its about intentionality. The amount of intentionality that goes into all the little things in a generative image is almost always closer to a client who's hired the photographer rather than the photographer themselves. Its a fuzzy line, I'll admit, but its very clear to me that the overwhelming majority of generative images out there on the "not art" side of that line. The few that are on the other side involve a very substantial amount of work by a human beyond the actual generating and selecting of the images that a real artistic vision of a human is present in the details of the image.

There is a considerable amount of shit photography in the world. My phone is full of thousands of examples. There is a considerable amount of shit generative AI images too, I agree. 

But you also admit that the best gen AI has an artistic vision realised by the user through their work. Sougwen Chung isn't just derping out minion memes, their exploration of the art form (or whatever you want to call it) has as much intention as all prior works she did. 

It seems like we agree that gen AI can be art at least some of the time, but you want to hold photography to a lower standard.

>But you also admit that the best gen AI has an artistic vision realised by the user through their work.

yes. but such examples can't fairly be described as generated images. They're so heavily modified by hand, or worked into broader art pieces that they are more fairly called "art that includes generated elements."

>It seems like we agree that gen AI can be art at least some of the time, but you want to hold photography to a lower standard.

I think you are confused about my position here.

As a basic starting position, I think that art must represent the vision of the artist.

I also think that, having a reasonably technical understanding of how image generators work, generative images do not, by default, represent any artistic vision. This has nothing to do with the quality of the image, or how closely it turned out to what the prompter had in their head. The details are not their artistic vision, they are the "vision" of an unthinking algorithm.

So by default, generative images are not art, and a generative image must be proven to be an exception if it is to be considered art.

A photograph, on the other hand, does represent the artistic vision of the photographer. Even if it is a poor or flippant artistic vision, it is still something that exists because a human saw something and thought "I find this aesthetically pleasing and wish to capture it", then used a tool to pick it out and isolate it from the broader context they found it in.

So by default, a photograph is art, and must be proven to be an exception if it is to be considered non-art (ie: the photo was taken by accident or something).

This isn't a lower standard, its the same standard. Its jut that generated images fail to meet that standard by default while photographs pass by default.

This is meant to be a sequel to the post I made yesterday about how by and large, VP picks are not typically announced within their home states in regards to the rally next Tuesday in Philadelphia, PA. With that in mind, here are some of my favorite potential picks for the VP spot.

Tim Walz: Very good as governor of Minnesota and has passed a ton of very positive legislation and beneficial policies. Both him and Beshear have also been endorsed as picks by the UAW. 

He may not be super well known on a national level, but I imagine he can have it built up very quickly with his fun Midwestern dad wit and character. His lieutenant governor Peggy Flanagan would be good in his place and can definitely win a reelection.

Andy Beshear: Also a pretty solid progressive. He can sway independent voters well and I think both leftists and liberals will be happy with him. He can also make for a really good contrast against someone like JD Vance.

JB Pritzker: Another very solid progressive governor from the midwest and has already been going through the same vetting process as the 2 other candidates above. I imagine he could also be good for keeping a strong Progressive/ Liberal coalition for the ticket.
